docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurance company, said yesterday that it would shed two million of its 19 million customers over the next year as it raises premium charges and struggles to make its troubled managed care business more profitable. The company also announced plans to eliminate 5,000 jobs, about 13 percent of its work force. The cuts, more than half from attrition, will include some reductions among its 2,300 employees in New Jersey.

headline.main: Aetna to Shed Customers and Jobs In Effort to Cut Health Care Costs

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc, nation's largest health insurer, will shed two million of its 19 million customers over next year as it raises premium charges and struggles to make troubled managed care business more profitable; announces plans to eliminate 5,000 jobs, or about 13 percent of work force; more than half of cuts will come from attrition, and will include reductions among its 2,300 employees in New Jersey; about 1.5 million of departing customers will be employees of companies that drop Prudential Health Care rather than pay steep premium increases; company plans to close unprofitable HMO's that insure 340,000 Medicare beneficiaries and sell or close health maintenance orgainzations that cover 300,000 to 350,000 employees of private companies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-20 Israeli Parliament Votes Not to Disband for Election The Israeli Parliament voted against dissolving for new elections, meaning that Israel will go to the polls in February to elect only a prime minister. Benjamin Netanyahu, a former prime minister who had considered running again, reportedly pulled out of the contest. A1

The company also announced plans to eliminate 5,000 jobs, about 13 percent of its work force. The cuts, more than half from attrition, will include some in New Jersey. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The Prudential Insurance Company of America took a big step yesterday toward shutting down its long-struggling investment banking business as part of its reorganization into a publicly traded company. The subsidiary, Prudential Securities, dismissed 160 investment bankers. The unit will now almost exclusively provide financial advice and sell insurance and securities through brokers -- an approach already adopted by prominent competitors. Prudential hopes to attract more wealthy clients to whom it can sell big insurance policies and investments for retirement. It also plans to expand sales to institutional investors like pension and mutual funds.

headline.main: Prudential Insurance Is Phasing Out Investment Banking Unit

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: SUSPECT SHOT IN ARREST A narcotics detective working undercover in the East Village on Saturday night shot a man who tried to rob him at knifepoint while steering him to a drug sale, the police said. The man, Oswaldo Vasquez, 43, was in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center with a gunshot wound to the chest. He was charged with attempted robbery and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. The police said the shooting, which happened in front of 226 East Third Street at 9:30 p.m., appeared to have been justified. The police said the detective, whose name was not released, was not hurt. Elissa Gootman (NYT) BRONX: GUNMAN WHO SHOT HIMSELF DIES A former domestic-violence counselor who the police say shot himself in the head on Saturday after fatally shooting his former girlfriend and her new boyfriend on a crowded Midtown street the day before died yesterday from his wounds, a hospital administrator said. The gunman, Daniel Sanders, 51, died at 5 p.m. at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, said Cynthia Balot, the administrator. Mr. Sanders had lingered for about 40 hours in critical condition. On Friday afternoon, the police said, Mr. Sanders fatally shot his ex-girlfriend, Doris Coleman, 40, and her new boyfriend, Lawrence Feaster, 41, near West 39th Street and Fifth Avenue. Then, early on Saturday morning, Mr. Sanders walked up to two detectives outside a Bronx police station and shot himself once in the head, the police said. Edward Wong (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: The managed care industry can hope to be reasonably prosperous next year, but many critics both in and outside the industry say H.M.O.'s will soon have to reinvent themselves, or perish. Bigger premiums next year should provide bigger profits for many. But higher costs in a number of areas -- in installing high-technology equipment, paying for new drugs and modernizing facilities -- are taking their toll. Hospitals and physicians are also rebelling against what they consider inadequate payments, and employers are railing against rate increases. Add to this legislation in Congress that supports patients' rights, and it becomes clear that the industry is under great pressure to re-evaluate its operations on many fronts.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Are Pressed on Many Fronts to Reinvent Themselves

docs.abstract: Managed care industry can hope to be reasonably prosperous in 2001, but both in and outside industry say HMO's will soon have to reinvent themselves, or perish; bigger premiums should provide bigger profits for many, but higher costs in number of areas are taking toll (Special section); chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The incoming Bush administration signaled today that it would make education its first legislative priority after taking office next month, and pledged to move rapidly on the other main pieces of its campaign platform, including a big tax cut and overhauls of Social Security and Medicare. In appearances on Sunday television news programs, Vice President-elect Dick Cheney and Andrew H. Card Jr., who has been designated as the new White House chief of staff, said they had no plans to scale back the conservative agenda on which President-elect George W. Bush ran.

headline.main: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT; Cheney Says Bush Administration Will Move Rapidly on Issues Central to Campaign

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton said today that more than eight million people had left the welfare rolls during his presidency, a nearly 60 percent drop. Speaking in one of his last weekly radio addresses, Mr. Clinton also hailed the new budget passed by Congress for providing hundreds of millions of dollars to offer health insurance to the poor, revive poor communities and renovate schools.

headline.main: Welfare Rolls Fell Steadily In His Tenure, Clinton Says

docs.lead_paragraph: 'I'll be back later,'' Tab Turner told his secretary as he rushed out of his North Little Rock law office, a file full of damning documents under his arm, a cell phone in one hand, a cup of coffee in the other. Brenda Gwin smiled but did not bother to ask what exactly her boss meant by ''later.'' Later could be 3 o'clock that afternoon or later could be one day next week. Even during normal times, Tab Turner is an incredibly busy man, a product-liability lawyer who has grown rich by specializing in sport utility vehicle rollover cases, who files scores of lawsuits each year against auto manufacturers. But lately, with rollover fatalities repeatedly being linked to the Ford Explorer and its recalled Firestone tires, Turner has been rocketing around the nation faster than a car with a sudden acceleration problem. Rarely is he in the same city two days in a row. New S.U.V. cases keep rolling his way; at the moment, he has 20 crashed Explorers and 50 mangled Firestone tires stored in a Little Rock warehouse for safekeeping in case he needs to produce them for trials against Ford or Bridgestone-Firestone.

headline.main: What's Tab Turner Got Against Ford?

docs.abstract: Michael Winerip article on Tab Turner, product-liability lawyer who has grown rich by specializing in sport utility vehicle rollover cases; discusses his focus on Ford Explorer and its recalled Firestone tires; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I read with great interest Edwin McDowell's article ''Cruise to Cuba Postponed Indefinitely'' (Nov. 19). I would like to advise your readers about activities of Sam Blyth, the president of Cuba Cruise. The last paragraph says: ''Last May, the second of two around-the-world voyages of the World Cruise Company, also headed by Mr. Blyth, was aborted in Papeete, Tahiti, stranding some 140 passengers. . . .'' Actually there was a third cruise, Northern Exposures, with a departure date of Aug. 4, 2000. The voyage was canceled with an unsigned form letter on June 7, 2000.
docs.abstract: Gaston A Schmidt letter warns other travelers about Sam Blyth's Cuba Cruise ventures; Blyth replies (S)
